Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Very small body that is easily pocketable Excellent, high-res, vibrant LCD Fast f/2 lens at wide-angle Optical image stabilization Front Control ring is handy for some controls Firm Mode dial Shooting-priority design means camera is always ready with a half-press of the shutter button Good auto WB in tungsten lighting Sophisticated white balance control Smart Auto with Scene Detection HDMI output Most compact camera with an f/2 lens Custom mode allows you to save and access your favorite settings quickly Better low-light focusing than G11 Adjustable center AF point size Similar noise performance to G11, though slightly stronger NR Faster startup than G11 (smaller lens) Faster full AF than G11 and LX3 RAW and RAW+JPEG mode Face ... detection, face self-timer Intelligent Contrast works well Digital Photo Professional software included Excellent printed results ISO 80 shots make a good 16x20-inch print ISO 3,200 shots make a decent 5x7 Low-light mode turns out usable 4x6-inch images up to ISO 8,000
Cons: Rear Control dial turns freely, which causes inadvertent exposure changes Front Control ring's function changes with the mode Zoom control takes too long to respond Flash is placed where fingers are usually in the way, preventing it from opening Power button is in bad position Only records VGA movies Only zooms digitally while recording movies Slightly soft images at default settings Lens not as good as G11's; softer at telephoto, high geometric distortion at wide-angle in uncorrected RAWs (but JPEGs are excellent) Moderate chromatic aberration, higher in uncorrected RAWs No optical viewfinder Lacks the ability to manually select an AF point other than center No noise reduction adjustments Flash exposure compensation seems to work in reverse (lower settings result in brighter images) Flash overexposes at min. distance Very uneven flash coverage at wide-angle Slower cycle-times than G11 and LX3 Sluggish flash recycling Lower-than-average battery life
To quite a few of us, an everywhere camera should be small. Hence the very positive response to the Olympus E-P1 and Panasonic GF1. But that's not small enough for many. I still carry a pocket digital camera for everywhere photography, and the Canon S90's major competition looks more like the Panasonic LX3 than the E-P1 or GF1. The Canon S90 seems to answer the call quite well, with an all-black body evoking the spirit of the company's EOS cameras, combined with a relatively pocketable profile. As I suspected in the Preview, the Canon S90 actually isn't thicker than the Panasonic LX3, coming in at 1.2 inches thick, compared to the LX3's 1.5-inch thickness. Panasonic's own sites say the camera is only 1.09 inches thick, but incredibly that doesn't include the lens bulge (Thanks to Nima Sa for the correction). Weight is also a little lower on the S90 when you add a card and battery, at 6.95 ounces (197g) compared to the LX3's 9.1 ounces (257g), quite different from their bare weights (sans battery and card). The Canon S90's lens reminds me of one feature that hasn't come back to the Canon G-series, because its maximum aperture is f/2.0. This changes to f/4.9 as you zoom (a little less than the old G6's f/2.0-3.0 range). Equivalent to a 28-105mm lens, the lens covers 3.8x range, and can focus as close as two inches. Canon's box-and-circle design is popular and often imitated, but this time the ring around the front lens element isn't just for decoration, it's a moving Control ring that you can program to perform one of several functions: Focus, ISO, Exposure, White Balance, and Zoom. It's important to note that there's no optical viewfinder on the Canon S90, so all adjustments will need to be made via the LCD. The Canon S90 still uses the ring around the shutter button for zoom control, only this time it's somewhat recessed into the camera's top deck. You can also see the Ring Function button that allows quick changes to what the front Control ring does. The pop-up flash is also strangely reminiscent of the Panasonic LX3. It rises and falls under motorized control, rather... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good photo quality; Roughly a full stop advantage over typical compact cameras in low light; Fast F2.0-4.9, 28 - 105 mm zoom lens; Optical image stabilization; Ultra high resolution 3-inch LCD with very good outdoor and low light visibility; Full manual controls, with white balance fine-tuning; RAW image format support -- good RAW editor included; Smart Auto mode picks a scene mode for you -- plenty of others to choose from yourself; Quick startup time, good focusing speeds (even in low light); Lots of customizable stuff: control ring and shortcut button, My Menu, custom spot on mode dial, self-timer; Redeye not a problem (much to my surprise); Handy face self-timer feature; Optional underwater case; HDMI output
Cons: Ergonomics are a real mess -- free-wheeling control di ... al makes it way too easy to accidentally adjust important settings, power and ring func buttons are identical and right next to each other, pop-up flash takes up valuable real estate on top of camera, control ring on front of camera a bit small, of limited use; Some shadow noise and NR artifacting in low contrast areas at base ISO -- mild vignetting and corner blurring at times; Sluggish continuous shooting mode; VGA movie mode seems a bit dated -- optical zoom cannot be used while recording; Flash is slow to charge; Zoom controller can be unresponsive -- current zoom setting not shown on LCD; Below average battery life; No optical viewfinder; No memory card included -- can't access memory card slot while using a tripod
When Canon announced the PowerShot S90, I was pretty excited. Manual controls and a fast lens in an ultra-compact body? Yes, please! My enthusiasm waned quickly once my review unit arrived. Not because of the picture quality or feature set, but because the usability and ergonomics are so poor. It's like Canon designed the camera without thinking that people's hands would actually be touching (witness the free scrolling dial, pop-up flash, and identical power/ring func buttons). The PowerShot S90 has impressive photo quality, a fast lens and nice LCD, and lots of manual controls, but using it was just too frustrating for this reviewer. Now, you may disagree with my assessment, and the the only way to find out is to try one yourself expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The Canon S90 is the latest compact DSLR replacement from Canon - the little brother to the successful Canon G11.
Profits are squeezed to the point of asphyxiation in the compact camera market at the moment; tough economic times mean your typical 'point and shoot' compact owner doesn't feel the urge to upgrade as often as makers would like.
There's also a bewildering range of new cameras to choose from. And of course, camera phones keep getting better and better.
Hence the rebranding of some compacts as 'SLR backups'. The term's a bit vague, but basically it refers to a compact camera which offers better optical quality and more sophisticated imaging options than your typical point-and-clicker - while still being very compact and easy to carry around.
The kind o ... f compact, in other words, that SLR owners would be happy to take as a backup, or use as their main camera when the SLR is just too big and indiscrete.
The Canon PowerShot S90 certainly falls into this category. It weighs in at a slimline 175g and is only about three inches deep with its 28-105mm lens fully extended.
At the same time, it shoots in RAW as well as JPEG and comes with Canon's Digital Photo Professional RAW-processing software, just as you get with Canon EOS SLRs. As well as SLRs, the Canon PowerShot S90 has a lot in common with Canon's flagship compact, the PowerShot G11.
You get the same 10-megapixel sensor, for instance, which as well as offering a very respectful resolution, does a sterling job of keeping digital noise down at higher ISO settings.
And while the Canon PowerShot S90 only has a 3.8x optical zoom lens compared to the 5x zoom on the PowerShot G11, the difference is not that huge. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Canon's PowerShot S90 compact digital camera is one of the most powerful point-and-shoot models that you can slip into your shirt pocket.
Canon's PowerShot S90 compact digital camera is one of the most powerful point-and-shoot models that you can slip into your shirt pocket. Much of the S90's appeal comes from its ability to overcome the shortcomings that often cripple compacts; it performs well in low light, has the option to capture in Raw format and it features an impressive set of controls that allow you to adapt the camera to just about any lighting situation.
The Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera can hide beneath a deck of playing cards. Its body measures 100x58.4x30.9mm and weighs 175g. You can slide it anywhere you have a spare pocket. It weighs half as much ... as its big brother, Canon's PowerShot G11, yet includes the same 10Mp, 1/1.7-inch CCD sensor and Digic 4 image processor. Both cameras feature crystal clear 461,000-dot LCD screens, but the S90's display is a 3in fixed-back version compared to the 2.8in vari-angle version on the G11.
You may wonder why the Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera captures only 10Mp while many of today's compacts can shoot 12Mp or more. The thinking is that if you put fewer pixels on a larger image sensor, you can better control image noise at higher ISO settings. Canon then developed a high-sensitivity system for its image processor to help optimize the data from low light shots. The result is that you can shoot at ISO 400, 800 and even 1,600 without destroying the image quality. This is a major step forward for a compact camera that sells for around £355.
The lens itself is an important component in this equation. The Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera includes a 3.8X optical zoom that has a maximum aperture of f2.0 for the 28mm wide-angle, then adjusts down to f4.9 for the 105mm telephoto. This means that when you shoot at 28mm, you have a very bright f2.0 lens that lets in a lot of light. Even at the 35mm zoom setting, the maximum aperture is f2.5, and at 50mm, a reasonable f3.2. The upshot is that the S90 features a lens that's extremely well suited for low-light photography.
Digital Photography Advisor
More compact camera reviews
Unlike many compacts, the Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera offers lots of control over the exposure and colour settings. The S90 features a mode dial on top of the camera, a control ring on its front and a control dial on the back. You rotate the top mode dial with your thumb to choose one of these exposure modes: auto, program, shutter priority, aperture priority, manual, low light, scene, movie and custom.
The rotating control ring around the lens on the front of the Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera is a true innovation. It's programmable, giving you the following choices: ISO, exposure compensation, focus, white balance or step zoom. All these functions are handy, but we preferred the step zoom setting allowing us to click-stop between 28, 35, 50, 85 and 105mm lens magnification. It feels very much like using a zoom on a digital SLR. Canon also uses the control ring to let you fine tune Auto White Balance. When you select the AWB function, you can warm up or cool down the color by rotating the ring to the left or right. I absolutely love this feature.
The control dial on the back of the Canon PowerShot S90 compact digital camera isn't as exciting, although it's a quick way to fine-tune the settings you've already established with the other dials. For example, when you're in programmed auto exposure, the back control dial can let you adjust exposure compensation. The problem is, there's no way to disable it. If you're not careful, you can accidentally brush your thumb against it and change the settings without noticing. Since the control dial is contextual, we recommend you program it to do the least amount of harm. We often shoot in aperture priority mode with the control dial used for changing the aperture settings. That way, if we accidentally brush it, we don't mess up our exposure,... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The Canon PowerShot S90 is a superb high-spec compact camera with the emphasis on image quality and controllable versatility. The range of features, build quality and results are excellent, although the fiddly controls and slightly sluggish performance are minor disadvantages. The only real problem is the extremely high price compared to rival models. One of the surprise success stories of last year was the Panasonic Lumix DMC-LX3, a premium compact camera featuring a 1/1.63-inch 10.1-megapixel sensor, a 3.0-inch 460k monitor, and an extremely high quality f/2.0 - f/2.8 wide-zoom lens. Costing a substantial £300 at launch it looked destined for the niche market of photography enthusiasts, but its combination of elegant retro styling, pocket-sized dimensions, high performance and superb ima ... ge quality proved to be a winning combination, and it sold so well that UK stocks of the black version almost sold out. /c6c385|2030_12261-canons903quart.jpg The popularity of such a seemingly exclusive camera must have come as a bit of a revelation to rival Canon, who had previously been the undisputed king of advanced compacts with its long-running and highly successful PowerShot G series. The LX3 put a dent in the sales of the PowerShot G10, so it comes as no big surprise that Canon's new Autumn line-up includes not just the impressive new PowerShot G11, but also today's review camera, the PowerShot S90. It's a welcome return for Canon's long-dormant S-series of advanced compacts. The S90's most recent predecessor was the PowerShot S80 launched in 2005. Although I'm sure that Canon would deny any connection, the similarities to the LX3 are hard to ignore. The S90 features a 1/1.7-inch 10.0-megapixel CCD (the same as the G11), a 3.0-inch 460k monitor, and a wide-zoom lens with a maximum aperture of f/2.0. It too has full manual exposure controls, an all-metal body and a very similar pop-up flash. It even has one of its controls on the lens bezel. /acdeb7|c4e6_12261-canons90front.jpg There are a number of significant differences however. For a start the S90 is considerably smaller and lighter than the LX3, measuring 100 x 58.4 x 30.9 mm and tipping the scales at approximately 200g including battery and memory card. The S90's lens is also quite different, with Canon opting for a 3.8x zoom equivalent to 28-105mm, whereas the LX3 has an extra-wide 2.5x zoom equivalent to 24-60mm. Both cameras have a maximum aperture of f/2.0 at wide angle, but for the S90 this drops to f/4.9 at the telephoto end, compared to the LX3's much faster f/2.8. The biggest difference however is the price. The S90 is currently selling for a whopping £400, making it one of the most expensive compact cameras on the market. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: S90 - You can take excellent photo even you are not a PRO!
Item.Review:
Pros: Great image quality; Packed with features; fast f/2 lenses; Full manual control
I was shopping for a replacement of my old point and shoot camera. I read a lot of reviews and finally decided to get this Canon S90 camera. I needed a low light capabiliyes for indoor and nighttime pictures especially without any flash.This small size camera did an excellent job on those photos with low-light with its fast F/2 lenses. Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Image Stabilization; Large Clear LCD; Small / Compact; Good Image Quality; Easy To Use; Good in Low Light
Cons: Poor ergonomics
I've taken about 500 pictures with my S 90 since receiving it at the end of October. Based on these, I offer the following comments.Positives:It takes great pictures. Color renditions, skin tones, exposure levels are all first rate. Higher ISO noise doesn't seem to be a problem. Image stabilization works well. The fast F 2.0 lens (at wide open) does wonders for low light no flash photography. For what it's worth, DxO makes pretty minor changes to S 90 pictures compared to what it does to D 40 pictures. A couple of sample pictures are attached for illustrationThe additional manual control wheels make the S 90 a great learning aid. I ... have the front wheel set for white balance tuning and the back wheel set for exposure control. The short cut button I have set for coarse white balance settings. Because the screen isn't cluttered with menus, I can see the effect of changes I make to the settings on the view screen before I take the picture. There's a little lag, maybe a second or so, but that's tolerable. My increasing knowledge of the effect of these settings has been transferable to my Nikon D 40 and D 90.Ken Rockwell claims the S 90 is the best pocket camera ever. That's pretty much why I bought it even though I already had a perfectly good SD950. As far as an aspiring amateur (me) can tell, he may well be right as far as the photography goes. Negatives:As has been noted in several user reviews, the placement of the on-off button and the shutter button are awkward, no where near as convenient as my SD950. Also, I can't tell if my finger tip is on the shutter release by feel like I can on the SD950. The S 90 shutter button is just more plastic under my aging finger tip.Doing a half press on the shutter button to lock exposure and focus is darn difficult. This adds a frustration that takes away from enjoying the camera and photography.The zoom control is jerky and seems to "bounce". That is, when you give it a nudge, it lags, then goes, then retreats back a little. This makes framing the picture much harder than it needs to be.The pop-up flash is a real pain in the posterior. I'm forever getting my left index finger in front of it. I don't think it would take much of a blow to break the flash. [$] The S 90 is harder to hang onto than earlier Canon pocket cameras I've had. After a couple of very lucky catches, I now make a real habit of putting the wrist strap around my wrist immediately after taking it out of the case.Conclusions:The primary purpose of a camera is to take pictures. The camera should make it easy for the photographer to concentrate on getting the picture right. The quality of its pictures and the benefits of the new ring controls more than makes up for the S 90's annoyances. However, these annoyances didn't have to be there. Canon makes other pocket cameras that don't have screwy flashes, poorly located shutter buttons, or jerky zoom controls.When all is said and done, I'm conflicted about what score to give the camera. Coming from the picture side, a 5 would be justified. From the operating side, it would only rate a 3. So, I'll chicken out and give it a 4. It's still the camera I carry around in my shirt pocket most of the time though.Making a long review longer, there's a review of the S 90 on Amazon that mentions a Kodak semi-hard case. I bought one and it works great. It just does hold the camera, wrist strap, extra battery, and spare SD card. The case provides good protection. I "bounce tested" it with the camera in it on a hardwood floor from about 4 ft. up with no damage. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: My goal was to stay with a point and shoot but have the ability to move up a notch in quality and the option to do more manually or explore things like depth of field when I was in the situation to do so. I have had it for two months and so far, so good. I like the size of it, the battery lasts a good long time, the colors and clarity are top notch. At first I felt like all images taken on auto were overexposed, but I found I had to get used to the way the camera senses light and just make sure I kept pointing it at varous locations within the image to get the exposure I really wanted before taking the pic. Hopefully that makes sense. It is a little slow, but I knew that when I bought it. If you want to capture a lot of fast motion, the camera will do a great job, but you may get ... frustrated with it at times. My favorite feature is one the scene options where you can select a color in the view finder to keep, and the rest of the image is black and white. For me, this makes my picture taking more fun and my scrapbooks more interesting. I could do this with editing software, but everyone who has done so will tell you it is very time consuming. This is well worth the investment! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use it for snorkeling and surf photography. Amazing how you can use all buttons easily under water. All buttons and dials are available, except rear dial. However, the rear dial's functionality can be used by simultaneously pressing Fn and the Left or Right arrows. But, I hardly use this. It does its main function - keeping the water and surf sand out of my S90 - best. Only issue I have is that the Shutter Button has a strong spring which gives you no tactile feedback. Pre-focussing is hard to do! So you get a lot of unwanted shots. If you press the button all the way down you get the P&S delay of anywhere between 1/2 and a full second. It's hard to chase fish with a P&S. (Get a DSLR if you need fast action!) Bring a big memory card and you'll be amazed what you can d ... o! However, you can't blame the housing for the short comings of the S90, you should know that. As far as value goes, 9 out of 10. Fun: 10 out of 10. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have used the camera for a couple of recent events: mountain biking, a night time trip around washigton dc, and a family party. the camera met or exceeded my expectations in each case. For mountain biking, fast movement in low light, i had to use higher iso 400+ to keep the shutter above 1/400. The image quality was much less noisy than i expected from a pocket size camera. I used the manual focus feature to reduce the shutter lag. when wandering around DC i forgot a tripod, however i was able to get some great, very sharp shots with long exposure and setting my camera on various surfaces. The photos have very great range, with completely black blacks and very good details on the engravings of bright white monuments. lastly at my family party i was taking shots of people indoors, ... these came out great especially when i used the HF-DC1 flash for a second remote light source. Others have commented on the battery life, to me it is just fine. Not as good as an slr, but considering the screen size and battery size there is only so much you can get. For me the camera size is the best feature and i will take the battery life. It can be maximized if you set the screen to the lowest brightness. Overall, i am very please with this camera, considering it fits in my jeans pocket and has done everything i have wanted it to. A+ expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: I can't put this camera down!
Item.Review: I bought this as a walk around camera for holidays so I didn't have to carry my dslr and lenses all day. Having read reviews on well known reviewer's site I decided to take the plunge and buy this amazing little camera. All in all this is a G11 that will fit in your pocket with the same manual controls and a faster f2.0 lens! The images at iso 80 are virtually noise free which, for a small sensor, is nothing short of amazing. The f2.0 lens drags in light which means I will be using it a lot for gig snaps too. This is definitely a photographers compact. White balance is great on the auto setting but even this is adjustable to your taste for amber/blue and also for magenta /green too. There are two programable dials one of which is around the lens, this i use for exposure compensation- the s ... etting is then displayed on screen as you use it. I do not have time to highlight all the pros in this review but if there was a shortcoming its the ease with which you can accidentally change the iso setting with the second control dial but I can live with that and I'm sure there is a menu setting to turn that off but I haven't looked in the manual yet, too busy shooting! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Before I make specific comments, I must say I just like Canon color, and the S90 doesn't disappoint. It simply looks rich and lively, unlike my Olympus 550WP which renders lifeless, grey and slightly washed out.I was ready to give up on point and shoot digital photography when I got the Canon. I need a reliable travel camera: small, relatively quick, with manual control. I recently returned from a long trip with the above Olympus which was almost worthless-slow, noisy, unreliable exposures...This was my second try at digital PnS and I was ready to smash the thing-it was so frustrating to use. So far, the Canon has exceed my expectations.So I was careful before purchase. I tried everything! Canon G11-too big and IMHO not worth the extra money for same processor and worse lens than S90. Oly ... mpus PEN-a second choice for me, but of the two I would have wanted the $1000 model. I felt for travel, I didn't want to drag lenses. The camera's a bit faster, the micro 3/4 processor is bigger, with the viewfinder and wide angle lens it feels a bit like a Leica-BUT I decided at the money, I'll just wait and get a Canon 7D and have a real camera. That said, I still like Canon S90 color better.I looked at Lumix GF1 and couldn't stand it. Very noisy at high ISO. I also don't like its color or menu set-up.I played with the $2000 Leica as well: this would have been my first choice, but no way do I pay 2K for a single fixed lens. Likewise with every other possibility-I just kept coming back to S90.REVIEW: This is not an SLR. However, the combination of size, color quality, manual set up, and camera intelligence make this unbeatable. In a pinch, AUTO mode gives quite nice results in most situations. However, I notice a tendency to blow out the whites. So I'm preferring P mode underexposing -1/3 to -1 stop with better results.I also manually preset the ISO to the lowest possible for the light condition, altho I've used the LOW LIGHT mode for night shots in the Lincoln Tunnel that I'm very happy with. I also shot a series inside the Metropolitan Museum of Art-low light, spot-lit art that came out great.The camera is fast enough for my purposes, with an adequate continuous mode. I'm a street photographer, and I need to capture an instant intuitively, without getting in my head to try to outsmart the camera. So far, the Canon is giving me living pictures I can use. My Olympus was USELESS in this regard.People complain about the back control ring moving too easily and changing settings. (And there are easy on-line mods for this). I, however, have found a left hand cradle grip that leaves the right dials alone. I purchased Richard Franieck custom grip which I've yet to use. I wish Canon would have made cleats on both sides of the camera so you can use a real neck strap. That said, I use the nice Lowe Rizzo 30 horizontal case with shoulder strap for pretty quick access to camera.I'm still learning the manual settings: the online Canon forums are useful for setting tips, as well as a couple of G11 books at [...]. For me, I like to keep it simple-Low ISO, keep the aperture in the sweet spot, keep exposure compensation in the back wheel, keep the flash off.I'm still learning about the focus options.For the most part, I'm happy to let the camera do the work. I LOVE THIS CAMERA. I ENJOY learning the camera. For my use, it's the ONLY camera out there: a great pocketable point and shoot, with manual controls. And at $350, it won't break the bank. The best performance vs price small point and shoot out there. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I love my Canon PowerShot S90 camera! It takes great pictures. It is has so many options, you can take great pictures in a number of ways. It takes beautiful movies too. I especially love the macro feature--you can focus down to 2 inches. The programmable function ring on the front is great for changing focus or zoom. You can shoot RAW, and the software for manipulating RAW files is very good. This camera does it all, and with DSLR quality. You can use it as a pocket camera on total auto for worry-free shots, or you can shoot manually like a pro. It has tons of features, and the battery lasts a long time. The low light capability of this camera is very very good. I am selling lots of my pro gear now because this camera is a lot more fun to use. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND the Canon PowerShot S90 if ... you want to have lots of fun taking great pictures. The only cons to this camera is that you cannot zoom while shooting video and the camera can be hard to hold while shooting. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Canon S90 Superior to Oympus Model: Tough 6020
Item.Review:
Pros: Great for taking pictures in dimly lighted low light without flash
Cons: Price is high for a point and shoot
Originally purchased an Olympus Model: Tough 6020 Black SKU: 9765213 for a cruise for the ruggedness and underwater capabilities. The camera was rugged and functioned underwater, but you sacrifice for blurry pictures and choppy video.
Returned it and added an extra $100 for a Canon S90 since it had good reviews and store display worked well. Mainly purchased it because it is easy to use and takes great pictures in low light without flash. I use it in night clubs to take pictures of bands without flash so it' not distracting. Great quality pics. Video is great quality as well. The camera is easy to use and has many great features.
Con - the button ... s are flush so it's hard to feel them which makes turning on and snapping photos and video hard in darkness. The telescopic button is on the photo button and very small so its difficult to use. the photo button is a half inch too far towards the center of the camera from the edge so you have to be aware of where your trigger finger is. the flash pops up from where your other hands finger naturally wants to rest so be careful.
The camera is great with these few cons aside. Even better if the price dropped by $75 to be more competitive. Watch pricematch with other stores because I save $25 after purchase. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: My criteria for choosing this camera was the best image quality in a pocket size camera. The size of this camera is about as big as I would want to go for it's purpose. I believe the image quality is at the top of as good as you can get for a camera of this size. I can't really compare it to other cameras in this class because this is the first P&S camera i've owned in quite a while (not including the iphone). The lens is as fast (f2) and as sharp as they come in a pocket camera. High iso I can't compare but seems to be about what I'd expect. It may or may not the best in it's class but when you factor in that it's about the only one that shoots raw that puts it over the top. It really only has one flaw for me. The little dial on the back right where your thumb always goes ha ... s zero friction. It rotates every time I touch it and I touch it every time I pick up the camera. The kicker is that the dial adjusts exposure in one way or another so I'm always bumping my exposure off. That's a big problem. A little friction would be nice, and indents would be awesome. I't might be a deal breaker for me. Actually another slight flaw is the on/off button could be in a better place and should have a little braille to make it findable without looking. My finger should be able to go right to it when pulling it out of my pocket. The rest are hopes and wishes. We're all looking for the one camera that does everything and that we can hold in our fingertips. And we get a little closer with every new model. This is the best you can get in a camera this size today. Would I like to have cleaner high iso's? Yes, but not at the expense of loosing megapixels. Would I like more megapixels? Sure, but not if they're gonna be all noisy in modestly low light. Same with the lens. A bigger zoom ratio would be great but it would sacrifice image quality or size of the camera. A longer lasting battery would be nice too. This one can easily run out in a day of shooting. Again I thing this is the best you can get without sacrificing size. Buy another battery. A pivoting screen (and brighter too) would make the camera far more versatile. And wifi and GPS would be cool too. Just don't make it any bigger. All in all I think Canon has made the best balance of image quality vs. size to date. Sadly, any day now there will be something better. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is a really nice camera. I wanted something lightweight and small but care about high image quality. So I chose this one. It has exceeded my expectations a bit. It will NOT replace a DSLR but is very good as long you understand its limitations. I really appreciate the control ring (around the lens). You can set the distance to say 28mm or 35mm or the like when in automatic modes. For manual modes (my favorite), it controls the aperture. I have a Canon Rebel XSi DSLR and I did not expect this S90 to beat my DSLR. To my surprise, this S90 is surprisingly competitive with my DSLR. In a way, for dark rooms with lots of underexposure, this S90 has LESS noise than my XSi! Otherwise, the XSi is better. I photograph dim rooms at F/2.0 with ISO 800 often and the results turn out ... nice! Dynamic range is surprisingly good. Downsides I found: The F/2.0 lens is for the wide 28mm setting only. Going to 35mm, you're at about F2.2 or F/2.5. 50mm is about F/2.8. It then goes downhill to F/4.9 at 105mm which is not that far. Its mainly a wide to medium angle camera. That's the price for a small camera. Keep this in mind. This camera comes with a wrist strap and I strongly recommend you to use it. Its not that easy to grip. Another downside is strong barrel distortion at 28mm. Canon's DPP program that comes with the camera will auto-correct RAW images so its not a problem. JPEGS are already auto-corrected out the box. Battery life may be short but I have not used it enough to be able to truly comment on that. The battery is so small, its easy to bring another anyway. Since getting this camera, I sold my 18-55mm lens that came with my XSi. This camera is SMALLER than that 18-55 lens! Getting a wide to medium angle lens that's fast for my XSi costs more than this camera... so I am taking both my XSi and this S90. The S90 does the wide angle work. It is that good... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I never read the reviews in B&H about this camera. But before I bought it I read multiple online reviews by expert reviewers such as those with Imaging Resource. Overall it seems to have been judged a competent picture taker. But most reveiws gave it poor marks for it's controls. Many e.g. went on at great length about how easy it was to mess up a photo by inadvertently moving the back ring control which has no detents. After using the camera for several days without reading the instruction manual I was ready to return it. Difficult to figure out what setting to use and so-so pictures most of the time. Then I read the manual. This manual is NOT meant for anyone over 40 even with bifocals. It has the smallest print and worst contrast of type to page I have ever seen. But it is ... well written and well organized. It starts out with beginner functions and a beginning photographer can stop there. Then it goes on the intermediate functions, especially the scene modes. An intermediate photographer can easily stop there. Finally there are advanced modes similar to what you see on an entry level DSLR like my Canon T1i. I began to realize that this camera should not be treated like an SLR. It is bought so that you can carry a camera with you, in your pocket, to take pictures at any time. Forget the advanced stuff unless you have a huge amount of time. Take it out, pick the correct intermediate function which takes just a moment, and you are ready to shoot. And in these semiautomatic modes the camera tells you what the controls do, and what they do changes with each setting and suddenly makes perfect sense. Use this as an always with you camera and you will not be disappointed. My last pocket camera was a Canon SD1100. It took a nice snapshot, most times, but not something you would want to enlarge or put on your wall. The s90 can take a picture that is just a small step down from an entry level DSLR! And that in the end is what it's all about. Finally a pocket camera, ready all the time, affordable, and capable of taking a near professional quality picture. PS, it does have significant shutter lag - that's just a function of today' level of technology. This is a P&S, not a DSLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Start with Pros of S90:
Excellent noise control, usable images up to ISO 3200; resolution below iso 1600 comparable to a DSLR. Compact – will slip into your jean pocket, but don’t sit with it. Useful front rotating dial, accompanied with the control dial on the back of the camera, allows control of 2 variable factors (ie. F stop & Shutter Speed, or ISO & Scene Selection) easily. Plenty of manual control, as well as a handful of fully automatic modes and scenery recognition system. Useful face recognition, great for parties and get togethers, not so good for selective focus. Plastic LCD front protective glass, less likely to crack, but respectable to scratches. Highly customizable white balance settings. Ability to shoot RAW data
Despite been a ver ... y capable camera, the S90 falls short in a few areas:
Incredibly short battery life – less than 180 shots in cold weather. about 200 in normal temp. You’ll want to have at least one backup battery with you. No HD Movie recording capability – most entry level P&S cameras got HD, why not this one? No autofocus or zooming during movie recording, basically renders movie recording useless. Back control dial is easily moved around by accident when holding the camera, resulting in unwanted exposure adjustments. On/Off button in an awkward position (right in middle of top cover), hard to reach for. Automatic popup flash will almost always get into your way, based on the way we hold our cameras. At telephoto end of zoom, aperture drops to F4.9 wide open, and max out at F8, very slow indeed. Noticeable shutter lag, autofocus may not lock when subject is moving.
It may seem like the cons are overwhelming the pros, but you should not be discouraged, this is by far the best compact point and shoot I have used. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Lovin' my new PowerShot s90 camera
Item.Review: I've had Canon camera's my whole life and they've always taken amazing pictures. I've only had this one a few weeks, but have taken it to a BBQ and around Manhattan taking photos. So far, this camera has taken some amazing shots that even surprised me. The colors were excellent and the shots crisp. I absolutely love that you can zoom in further than the 3.8x that it says you can and still get fairly spectacular shots. The menus are easy to use and intuitive. For some reason, I keep missing the click button, but I think I just have to get used to my new camera. I haven't had a chance to use the manual functions yet, so I cannot speak to those. All in all, a great camera at a decent price.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Excellent pictures from this compact P&S camera.
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy to use, Great pictures, Compact size
Cons: Price kind of steep
I've owned many small digital cameras, the most recent being a Canon SD990. Saw the Canon S90 in store and thought to give it a try. Wow, what an awesome digital camera. It's compact, svelte body is a huge plus...but, the best feature is the excellent pictures this camera produces - fine details and great colors. Canon got it right with this S90! The S90 has an f/2.0 lens (only other compact camera that I know has it is the Panasonic LX3 which is $500) that allows for great indoor shots without the use of a flash. The unique rotating dial around the front lens allows for quick changes of certain functions and the camera features a low-light mode. I am very happy with the S90 and can highly recommend it. ... .. though the $429 price is a little steep. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: f2.0 lens, large CCD sensor, large LCD, wide angle lens, control ring, night shots
Cons: No HD video, a little large
I started off with an SD960is, but was really disappointed with the image quality, especially on darker scenes. It was compact, shot HD video, and would probably suit 9 of 10 people perfectly, but I'm too much of an IQ snob and night shot person to live with it.
So, I traded up to the S90 and couldn't be happier. The f2.0 lens is amazing, I don't believe there there are any other P&S's out there with anything better then a 2.8. Combine the fast lens with the 1/1.7" CCD (not CMOS) sensor and you get amazing night pictures, and fantastic quality all around. Even though it's "only" 10MP, the IQ far surpasses that of the 12MP SD960is. Fully manual ... mode is great and intuitive, the control ring allows quick adjustments of anything you need (ISO, shutter speed, focus, zoom, white balance, etc). The camera also powers up in less then a second, great for saving battery life but not missing that great shot. Shutter response is good for a P&S, but obviously not instantaneous like a DSLR.
As far as I am concerned, I don't think you can get a better P&S if you are anything more then a casual photographer. Most reviews you will find on the web and in magazines agree. My only gripes are lack of HD video, and it's just a tad on the large side because of the lens/control ring. Most photography purists are on board with lack of HD video, but I think it's a simple feature that would have been nice to have. The size really isn't an issue, still small enough to fit in a pocket, but it's just a hair too large to fit in the "small" size cases so you will have to look at something in the medium range.
Bottom line: Buy an S90 and you will never look back. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Use the product for travel photography, did not want to lug my Canon D50. Great pictures, ability to control exposure and different modes are a big plus. Fits in your pocket. Did not have a problem with battery life as other people have reported, but used it for a lot of daylight photography without flash. The only downside is that the zoom only goes to about 105mm, there were some situations where I wish I had more zoom. However, if I was going to take my DSLR with me, I made the decision to only take one lens to cut down on bulk and weight. That was my 28-105mm, so I can't say I would have done any better. The trade off is for a faster lens with great image quality at pretty much all focal lengths.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Lots of features and excellent picture quality for a great price
Item.Review:
Pros: Packed with features; Reasonably priced; Easy to use; Great image quality
Cons: Flash gets stuck easily if pressed on
I recently got married and wanted to buy the best compact digital camera I could afford -- we needed one for the honeymoon, knew we'd be adopting a puppy when we got back, and also wanted one that would take great photos when we start having children in a couple of years.
After spending hours scouring the Internet for both professional and 'end user' reviews, I chose the Canon s90.
I'm definitely an amateur photographer, so I love the fact that the "Auto" setting on this camera works so well. However, it's easy to learn to use the other modes, turn the flash off and on, etc., and make other custom adjustments if you need to do so. The use ... r manual is detailed yet easy to understand even for a 'newbie'.
This camera is absolutely packed with features. Menus are easy to navigate; settings such as the screen brightness, shutter sound, startup sound and image, navigation click sound, and volume for all of the above sounds, as well as for the video playback, can all easily be customized. You can even do some basic photo editing of images with the camera, such as applying sepia, B&W and other effects, adjusting color, etc.. As you shoot, it will also display the number of pictures for which your card has room remaining, given the quality you're currently using (fine or normal).
Its face detection and auto focus works extremely well. The only problem is with very fast-moving subjects, but that's going to be a problem for any camera in this class.
My family has owned a number of Nikon and Sony digital cameras in the $250-$350 range in the past and the s90 takes far better pictures than any of them, especially in low light. Downloading to my PC is quick and easy with the included software.
The s90 also shoots pretty good video, though it's not high-def. You can zoom in and out while shooting, and the sound is clear. With a 2 GB card, you can shoot about 24 minutes of video, while an 8 GB card will hold an hour and a half. One warning about shooting video -- it consumes both the battery and the storage space on the card rapidly. For example, with my 4 GB card, I'd been shooting for a few days; I had space for about 1000 photos left, and then shot about 15 or 20 minutes of video, and saw that my estimate of photos remaining had dropped to just 80 or so. The battery, which had been at about 3/4 charge, was getting low as well. (Canon estimates the battery should last through 225 photos, but doesn't give an estimate for video).
I've had the camera for a couple of months now and the only issue I've had (and it's a common one) is getting the "wrong flash position" error due to having accidentally pressed on the pop-up flash when it was shooting. This can sometimes be corrected by restarting; one time, the error persisted and I found that by gently pulling up on the flash with my fingernail, it was fixed.
All in all, this is a great camera for those who aren't looking for a cheap camera, but also can't afford (or don't want to lug around) an SLR. The features and image quality can't be beat for the price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: i bought this camera for almost one month. Actually i have already had a professional digital camera ,but it's too heavy. so i bought this one again. it's actually beyond my expectation. i love it very much. it's not as heavy as the professional one,so that i just put it in my purse when i go everywhere. so i can make a wonderful picture whenever i want. it can make the picture in very good quality which is almost the same to those made by professional camera, especially the color is so good. and it's very convinient because it can choose the best model automatically. it also has the function of making movie. i love it. i uses it for everyday when i go to musemums , beaches, central park and everywhere. Of course it also has the thins that is not so great. i don't like the battery very muc ... h. but that maybe because i take too many pictures at one time. if you don't make more than 300 pictures in three hours , i think it doesn't matter. i love my camera, Canon s90 . i love its color, it's so cool, i love the pictures it makes, i love the case, and almost everything about it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Good intermediate camera with few issues
Item.Review:
Pros: Good in Low Light; Nice features
Cons: Limited Zoom; Questionable design
This camera was bought as a large step up from an ancient point and shoot digital, and as a lighter camera to carry around when my SLR is just too much. Bought the S90 based on the awesome f/2.0 and full manual capabilities in a small package. LOVE it for lower light conditions, special shooting modes, full manual made pretty easy with limited buttons. Took over 1000 pics with a quick learning curve and few problems. The problems: I miss being able to go above f/8 for shallow depth of field. Have to suck it up- it's a point and shoot. Occasionally find the auto focus to be less than...working. Optical zoom is limited, and digital zoom is frankly horrible. But the biggest complaint- the pop-u ... p flash is right under where your left index finger wants to be to hold the camera steady. If you try to turn on the flash (or if the camera decides to in Auto) and your finger is on, it will get jammed and you have to reset the camera. After 3 months and maybe 10-12 times of this happening, it got permanently jammed. Will still work if I lift with my fingernail, but frustrating. No need for it to have been pop-up when it could have been open on the front of the camera. Overall great pics, and happy with the money I spent...assuming Canon will fix the flash for me. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Back To Basics (But Not For Cheap)
Item.Review:
Pros: Well-designed interface; Good Image Quality; Compact; Lots of features; Good in Low Light
Cons: Limited Zoom; Easy to drop; Expensive
There are an abundance of insightful reviews about this camera out there to be found, but from my first few weeks of use, if you know what you're getting, you're bound to be pleased. It's not a super-zoom, and it's not quite an ultraportable, and it's a little too expensive to justify keeping it on Auto all the time. By my estimation, it's a *very* capable, highly customizable, compact point-and-shoot designed with image quality as a first priority.
Compact though it may be, it doesn't lend itself well to one-handed operation: I haven't dropped it yet, but I've already been saved by my wrist strap a few times. For what it's worth, ... the build quality seems good, though I'm not about to try my luck against gravity and pavement.
Though I miss a well-defined grip, the intuitive Control Ring on the front gives you a reason to bother having two hands on the camera -- it lets you assign it to your setting of choice (ISO, exposure level, manual focus distance, and so forth). It's definitely a triumph of design interface, and makes the camera's potency a lot more accessible to those who aren't keen on sifting through menus before every shot.
As a small sticking point, you can't double-assign the same setting to both the control ring and the menu wheel on the back, or turn one or the other off altogether. I get why, but it would be nice to totally idiot-proof my setup, especially since the menu wheel is pretty easy to jostle. Generally speaking, though, the Control Ring is far more blessing than burden.
The camera's low-light shooting prowess is a big selling point, and you needn't use the Low Light setting on the camera to take advantage of it: the lens has a maximum aperture of f/2.0, the image processor keeps most grain away even up to ISO 800, and the image stabilization is decent. Certainly, if you're just after a quick snapshot of where you were, rather than something you might wind up printing, you're in fantastic shape.
The S90 offers a large range of manual control, though its lens isn't quite magic enough to make Full Manual a worthwhile default -- I use it on Program Mode, and hop to Shutter Priority when a situation calls for it. If anyone can offer a practical use for Aperture Priority mode, I'd sincerely like to hear it.
Its video is pretty unremarkable, but that's not an issue for me -- I feel like the emphasis was clearly on taking good pictures, period. On the flipside, if you're a doofus like me who loves taking extreme close-ups of just about anything, the S90 has a very strong macro mode.
Phew. Hope this all helps! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: GREAT little P/S to compliment DSLR
Item.Review: I was looking for a good quality P/S to take with me on family outings, or just to always have with me. I am currently shooting the Canon 5dmk2 but that is not a setup that you want to take everywhere you go. I wanted a camera that had RAW capture and good quality images. The S90 is not going to have DR or quality of a DSLR but it is very appropriate for everyday shots that you don't want to miss. It is 110% better than the camera you don't have with you because it was too cumbersome to carry!! It is very compact, which was the whole point for me. I wanted a camera to go in my purse or pocket. If you get bigger than this you start to defeat the purpose of ultra portability. Some think that the S90 is fumbly without the after market grip. I personally don't have an issue with it but I do h ... ave small hands. I will echo the fact that the dial on the back is all too easy to hit and change settings by mistake. Probably my only real complaint. I would definitely recommend the S90. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Nice little Point and Shoot with manual
Item.Review:
I bought this camera to use as a point and shoot underwater in connection with Canon's DC-35 underwater camera housing. There are a lot of camera models out there that have housings to go with them, but most of the cameras do not have both compact size and manual controls. That and I have had good experience with Canon's digital point-and-shoot cameras.
I used it mostly on automatic above water and it handled low light, sunsets, nature, scenes and portrait pictures well. Underwater I used it exclusively on manual and adjusted the aperture, shutter speed, and ISO as well as used the automatic white balance for underwater. Most of the closeups were right on and well lit, but most subjects farther away than 2 feet were bluish - even with the flash and diffuser.
I only used vid ... eo rarely but it seemed to capture video fine.
Overall I feel that I got the best, smallest, lightest, manually-controlled camera on the market at the time and I would do it again. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: While by no means a professional photographer, I studied photojournalism and studio photography in college. I understand and use most of the capabilities of the cameras that I own. I had a Panasonic DMC-FZ8 that I unfortunately damaged when I dropped it. I was quite happy with the quality of the images of that camera, but wanted a smaller point and shoot that I could take anywhere, especially to take pictures of my one-year-old. There are numerous amazing things about this camera. I have only had it for a few days, but the F2 lens is remarkable. I am usually expecting the flash to go off, and often it doesn't and the image is still amazing even in low light. The size is great, and the amount of control that I have over the settings are exactly what I was looking for. My only complain ... t so far is that the flash pops up automatically and I am not used to where to put my hands, so it often bumps my fingers. The camera is quite small, so there aren't many places to hold it. Once I get used to that, I am sure it won't be a problem. The camera is quite solid and feels like a real camera in a small size. The zoom is limited, but the digital zoom is passable. One of the coolest aspects is that you can turn the ring on the front of the lens and change quickly from 28 - 35 - 50 - 85 - 105. Overall I think this camera is fantastic. Whether you have a clunky SLR and want a backup or just want a small camera that you can really control all the settings and takes AMAZING pictures, this is for you. I am thinking at some point I will get my dream clunky high-powered SLR, but I might find that I don't need it after having this. I almost didn't get this because it does not have HD, but that would have been a huge mistake. I am a believer in not expecting one reasonably-priced tool to do everything. The picture quality is fantastic. Also, the video DOES zoom while filming. That is a big plus that my Panasonic didn't do, and it would drive me crazy. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I purchased this to replace to my faithful G7. I use this camera for travel when the 50D stays home and for get-togethers with friends and family. The picture quality from the S90 is amazing for such a small camera and much better than the G7, which I also love. Having RAW capability is all the more valuable when you capture that perfect travel shot you wouldn't want to lose. Colors are vibrant and distortion is low execpt for the edges at the widest angles. I've found fringing also to be very good. ISO performance is good up through ISO 400 where the G7 was much degraded by ISO200. I have captured shots in an almost totally dark room at ISO 3200 with acceptable results for what it is - meaning that there is quite a bit of color noise. The S90 handles ok but it is so small that kee ... ping a grip can be difficult. I added a finger grip that solved this problem. As others have said, the pop-up flash can dislodge your left hand but I normally control the flash manually, so it doesn't surprise anyone. Also, the ring on the back is easily moved by accident, changing your exposure so I make confirming the exposure bias on the monitor a matter of habit. The control ring around the lens is nothing short of genius and now couldn't live without it. Although I've heard that battery life wasn't that good, I've found it to be quite acceptable and only once had to change batteries during one day of shooting. This camera will go everywhere I go. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Super great camera with fun options
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD; Nice Body Color; Good in Low Light; Small / Compact; Good Image Stabilization; Great Zoom; Good Image Quality; Short Lag Time; Easy To Use
Husband and wife purchased this product for Valentine's Day. Wife is accomplished photographer, husband a casual phototographer.
This is a perfect camera to fit into a bag or a pocket and get excellent photos. The camera has adjustments that work well under unusual conditions. Camera body is very nice also.
Gary at Adorama answered all our questions and assisted us with all the required options. Purchased wonderful camera bag, fast memory card, and extended warranty.
Such a wonderful experience my husband sent his brother and our sister-in law to Adorama to see Gary and purchase the same items the fo ... llowing week.
Used this at Sesame Street live and took great pictures of all the characters. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Excellent start up time and shot to shot recycle time - even with flash. Nearly all the options an advanced photographer could ask for while giving the beginner a great unit to grow into. Out of the box it's Auto-Aim-Shoot. I like the ring control around the lens for SLR-like zoom control. Although I'm a Nikon SLR user, no one beats Canon in this format. If you want great picture quality and amazing low light capability (simple amazing for this lens) just buy this camera. No HD movies but still very very good quality. Flash pop-up is a bit inconvenient but helps (a little) with red eye. Easy to have your finger over it as it tries to deploy. Overall a great value in a powerful package.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Best pocket camera for mid level user
Item.Review: Excellent pocket camera if you want control. Amazing in low light. Expensive. Most drawbacks are due to Canon trying to stuff everything we want into a smallish package. You pay for available light abilities and relatively wide angle lens. If you do not want lots of control over the image, there are better choices for you money that are smaller. Pros: good controls, low light, wide angle lens with good zoom range, good controls, excellent finish. Cons: cost, flash pops up into my finger, no rangefinder (shortened battery life), exp compensation adjustment easy to bump, smallest aperture limited to 8

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: great little cam for serious photography
Item.Review: I bought the S90 to have a camera that is easy to carry at all occasions and that offers not only powerful automatic photography but also enables to operate in full manual mode. The front ring (exactly feeling like a classic aperture ring) can be used to adjust aperture, but can also switched to set time, white balance or ISO-settings. Absolutely amazing. The fast (1:2) lens together with the electronic stabilizer enables available light photography on a new level (for such a small camera!). The one and only thing missing is a system flash interface. Taken together: Exactly what I was looking for, best in class.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Low light quality - available workable accessories - function ring on lens barrel.
Cons: Nothing negative about it.
Purchased this camera for its low light ability and the function ring on the lens barrel. It clips to my belt loop and I can comfortability take it anywhere. Low light pics are sharp and detailed. The aftermarket accessories are workable and greatly add to the compact digital. The real test was use in extremely foggy conditions on a river in drizzling rain. Pics of tow boats slipping away in the fog were detailed and color surprising good despite thick fog. Very realistic imaging. Moisture and drizzle did not affect the camera or its operation. Dried it off and kept on snapping shots. The camera fulfills every expectation. This camera was not purchased for ... video so that operation isn't important to me. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Fantastic camera to always have with you
Item.Review: I've been using this for about a week now and I am very pleased. Having used a Canon G10 extensively, I found that camera too big still in many situations when I left it behind due to its bulk. The S90 offers practically the same levels of quick response and solid image quality in a slim package that easily fits in a jeans pocket. It should be noted that the lens does not perform quite as well as that of the G10 - notably some corner softness and increased distortion is evident upon close examination. However given the one stop faster aperture (f/2.0) and extremely compact size, this is easily forgivable. The new sensor delivers excellent colours at high ISO values and the in-camera noise reduction does a very good job. If you shoot JPEG or at least use Canon's DPP raw conversion softwar ... e, distortion will be automatically corrected (though not 100%). However if you plan on using a third party raw converter, you may want to look into PTLens which can fully correct the images. Sometimes I wish Canon had found a way to provide a detachable fixed viewfinder. The rear dial does not click and the on/off button cannot be operated with your right hand while holding the camera. I would have also preferred to manually raise and close the flash. These are small niggles however. All in all, this is a well put together compact which any power user will be perfectly comfortable shooting with. No more excuses to leave home without a camera, and you won't feel shortchanged that you didn't bring the DSLR! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I carry this camera w/ me everywhere that I go. The lightweight and compact form factor make it much more appealing than my Tenba rolling case and 50d. The quality of the shots in low light is amazing! I've taken photos in dark rooms w/ only the light of a tv/computer monitor and the camera produced excellent quality shots with minimal graininess. I really chose this over the G11/10 because of the form factor and the ease of changing functions (there aren't knobs stacked everywhere on the body). Pros: best quality photos for form and size. Ease of use and great quality photos at high iso w/ little or no light. Cons: Video is still only VGA. Conclusion: This is a great all around camera for the non pro and pro alike. I actually have used it for magazine editorial photos and found no iss ... ue w/ photo quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great prosumer compact; wish it was fast
Item.Review: This camera replaced my aging Canon Digital Elph. Its slightly larger but can still fit (tightly) into my front jeans pocket. I wanted to get as close as I could to a DSLR without the bulk and this camera acheives it. I use this camera to shoot pictures of my kids and landscapes. The larger CCD and F/2.0 lens are the big draws. The ring controls on front and back, combined with the programmible button on back mean that I rarely dive into the menus. The camera remembers my preferences for each mode and lets me store one custom mode. Biggest con is speed and screen blanking. My older SD300 was faster (3Mpix) even though I only shoot at 4Mpix now. Most significantly, the screen blanks during the shot AND file transfer. For continuous shots or bracketed shots this means you have no i ... dea what's going on. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: washed out LCD, inaccurate ISO ratings
Item.Review:
Pros: F20 lens; Aperture ring
Cons: Washed out LCD; Inaccurate ISO ratings
1. Washed out LCD screen color 2. ISO rating one stop under listing 3. Overly contrasty images from RAW and JPG 4. Slippery surface
The S90's LCD screen is very washed out making it difficult to evaluate one's exposure. Skin tones are particularly washed out.
ISO rating is appears to be incorrect. The "Sunny 16 rule" does not work with the displayed ISO in Manual. Example: Metering off a grey card in direct mid-day sun should yield an exposure of ISO 80 with f5.6 and 1/640s. Instead the proper settings to reflect accurate exposure at ISO 80 are f5.6 and 1/320s. ISO set at 80 performs as if it were ISO 40. In fact, testing ISO 200, 400 and 800 all revealed that their tr ... ue sensitivities appear to be ISO 100, 200, and 400. Hence, noise levels 'appear' lower at ISO 800 than normal for a PowerShot camera, when in reality, the noise levels should be compared to ISO 400 as this is the true sensitivity.
Images appear artificially contrasty in RAW or JPG Fine. Shadows are nearly black with no detail without pumping them up in RAW images using Canon's own DPP software. Images shot with prior Canon models had smoother detail in the shadows.
The S90 has a beautiful casing. It would benefit from some texturing. The surface is incredibly smooth and slippery making it challenging to hold.
Overall, this platform has great potential. Love the 'aperture ring' and compact size. Would like to see the return of SuperFIne compression in Canon's PowerShot lineup. Fine compression simply has too many artifacts especially evident in flesh colors, and large areas of the same color. Very noticeable when viewed at 100%. f2.0 lens a huge plus. Thank you Canon for paying very good detail to the lens! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Best compact camera I have ever owned
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality, low-light capabilities, manual controls, RAW, control ring/dial
Cons: Average battery life, no HD video (if it matters to you)
I decided to purchase a new pocket camera to take on a trip to Disney World. I needed low light capabilities for indoor and nighttime pictures without a flash and a wide angle lens. I purchased two cameras and compared them for several days prior to the trip. The two cameras were the Sony WX1/B and the Canon S90. Each has its advantages and disadvantages. The Sony is smaller, has better battery life, and does HD video. It has some unique and interesting modes including the rapid 10 shot and slick panoramic modes. The Canon has faster glass (f/2.0), full manual controls, a unique flexible control ring/dial, RAW capability, great ... build quality/feel and very low noise levels for a pocket camera. Its battery charger requires only two hours. The downsides of the Sony include a slow included battery charger (6 hours but you can buy a faster charger for $50), cheaper build quality/feel, and really poor auto white balance requiring constant manual tweaking. The contrast and exposure levels on the Sony images were also inconsistent and almost always worse than those on the Canon requiring a trip to Photoshop for corrections. The Sony also had higher noise levels at all ISO values than the Canon. The downsides of the Canon are it's larger size (but still pocketable), the lack of HD video, worse battery life (buy a second battery) and its narrower zoom range (28-105 mm equivalent vs. the Sony's 25-120 mm). The bottom line was that I was getting a camera mainly for pictures and while I will miss the HD video and some of the Sony's special modes, the picture quality of the Canon was superior to the Sony. Its low light capabilities were also greater with the faster lens, its own lower resolution high sensitivity mode, and lower noise levels. I returned the Sony and kept the Canon. I took about 700 pictures and shot about 50 videos with the Canon on my trip and feel that I clearly made the right choice. While the Sony was good, the Canon was the winner for me. Even in auto mode, t ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Low noise, high quality 1/1.7" sensor, easy manual adjustments on two dials, and all in a compact form factor
Cons: For its class nothing
This camera does exactly what is advertises to do. It takes great pictures and is capable of taking high quality low light pictures. I have taken several pictures in low light environments at varying ISO levels. The pictures come out wonderfully with little noise. There is noise, but I feel the amount is more than acceptable. By using the front dial as well as the wheel you can change several manual adjustments on the camera quickly and easily. One earlier review docked this camera down for having so many adjustments and "would take time to learn", but if you're complaining about it why did you get it. It's a advanced compact not a po ... int and shoot. The thumb dial can be annoying sometimes when you hit it and change a setting or move to another picture. I think it will just take some time getting used to. This camera does not have HD video, but it is not meant to be a video camera. It takes videos well at its standard 640x480 resolution. at 30fps. It is expensive, but for the feature set you essentially are getting a entry level SLR in your pocket. On a feature basis it is very comparable to the G11 and actually beats it by have a fast f/2.0 lens. If you want to take great pictures in a variety of environments I recommend taking a look at this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: My first underwater pictures turned out really great on my latest trip to Cozumel. I found that the flash was nearly useless and used the battery fast, making it best to take pictures when sunlight penetrates the surface. Deeper than 6m (or murky water) would require a separate strobe. Also, setting the review display on hold emptied the battery quickly, but after turning this off, I could snorkel for four hours. I'm used to using SLRS so it's annoying how long it takes from you press the shutter until the picture is taken. I also found that the camera automatically adjusts the shutter speed even if it's on shutter speed priority (could be that there's a way to fix this that I don't know), and this gave many blurry photos, but with an OK exposure. But the bottom line is, this camera ho ... using opened up a new world to me. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The camera is nice and compact - definitely small enough to slip into a pocket or purse. It operates quickly and takes good shots. The S9 is also one of the cheaper, high quality ultra-compact cameras that you'll find. Unfortunately, with the money that you save, I would recommend that you get a spare battery since the battery life of the camera is not amazing. It would probably make it through a weekend vacation, but that's about it.
The camera is definitely not meant for an advanced shooter, or someone who wants to tweak settings until they get just the right shot. There are no manual exposure controls, so you're stuck with adjusting white balance, sensitivity (ISO), exposure compensation, or using the built in scene modes. However, I would still recommend the S9 for someone ... looking for an ultra-compact camera with some style and an affordable price. The camera is good for snapshots, and the one touch button to access Nikon's portrait mode with Face Priority AF provides quick access to the optimal settings to capture your friends having a great time.
Pros
Good image quality
Nice size and attractive styling
Good price for an ultra-compact
Cons
Disappointing battery life
Red tones challenged the camera
Loud zoom motor expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Great image quality; Easy to use
I got this camera about a year ago. I was looking for a camera that was more than a point and shot but not all the way up there with the DSLRs. I got just what I was looking for! This camera takes great pictures in low-light settings the quality is great! I also love the look of the camera. However one thing that I do not love about the camera is its size. However, it is still small enough to fit in my purse and its not too heavy. One other thing that is a little wierd about the camera is the flash that pops up. For people who have not used this camera before get a little confused when the flash pops up from the top of the camera. I have also noticed that when other people take pictures with my camera, they tend to have a hard time pushing the ... botton all the way to take a picture. Howver, I have never had any problems with that. The functions are easy to use and it takes great videos as well. Overall I love this camera and Canon in general. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am going to be snorkeling for 10 days and was looking for the best water shooting strategy. I don;t plan on doing much water shooting after this, so I was hesitant to buy a housing. So instead I bought a Canon D20 which can be submerged to 30ft. However when I tested in a pool the pictures were simply not sharp. So I sent it back and bought the housing for my Canon S90. The difference is night and day. I was afraid the glass on the housing would impact the pictures. While I am sure it does have some impact on quality -- I just have not blown the images up enough to check. But it is so obviously better than the D20.The controls work very easily -- the only issue, mentioned by others -- is that you can turn the dials. Therefore you need to shoot in program mode -- that will giv ... e you control of everything from the buttons on the casing.All and all, really worth the price -- expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Camera with a couple of issues
Item.Review: This is a great camera but does require a little manual input. So if you want a very basic point & shoot, I would not recommend it. But if you are willing to put in just a couple of hours to play and experiment with, it's a terrific camera. Very fun and takes great photos. I needed a camera that excelled in low-light and very bright conditions and this one definitely does the trick. I also like that it's small but the screen is big. My only complaint is that the flash is located in a bad place. It pops up and we always put our fingers on it, missing the first chance for a photo. Also the shutter button on the top is also located in a bit of an odd location. I'm sure we'll get used to both though so it's really only inconvenient when someone else takes a photo with our camera. I'd still ... buy the same camera though again as the photos are beautiful and it's fun! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: We bought this case to take pictures at Niagara Falls, and we're very glad we had it during our ferry ride and walk along the bottom of the falls. The case itself is sturdy, easy to use, and the picture quality is still excellent. The only negative is that you can't adjust the camera settings once it's put in the case. Otherwise, we're very pleased with it and figure it was a great investment that opens up all kinds of opportunities for taking photos.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Easy to use high end point and shoot camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy to use
Cons: Battery doesn't last as long as other digital cameras I've had
I did a lot of researching before purchasing this camera. I consulted friends and beginner professional photographers. I read reviews for hours, asked the Best Buy sales clerks and in the end this was my first choice.
After owning Kodak Easyshare cameras for the past 5 years, this camera is a breath of fresh air. It is compact enough to fit in your pocket or purse. It has automatic settings that choose the best scene for the picture you are taking. It is easy to use and takes nice, clear pictures.
If you want to get artistic, you can play around with the manual settings as well.
Several people complained about the position of the flash. I have not experiences any issues ... with this. You just have to adjust where you place your left index finger. You get used to it right away. Also, some have complained about the grip of the camera. I also have not experienced any issues with this.
So far I love this camera and look forward to playing around with it more to experiment with different types of shots. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Bot this camera to replace my G9 that had "no power" issues for a second time in a year and was sick of repairing it. Was worried that the small size and my generally shaky hands would overpower the IS, not true. Was also worried about the control wheel on the back and have had zero issues accidentally bumping it. Picture quality is excellent, fits in the pocket great and is an excellent camera that hides in an unassuming shell. Also, bot this for $340 on closeout, wouldn't have held out for the S95, just not enough amazing features.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot S90 10 MP Digital Camera
